What is this?
	This was the final project for Advanced Programming, a class I took at UChicago in the Fall of 2020. I implemented a huffman coder and decoder using C. I include a .txt file for testing, but this program works to decode any .txt file containing visible ASCI characters.


How to Run?
	make
	./huffman
	Takes interactive command line arguments as specified in assignment. Invalid commands will lead to error messages.

High Level Description of my approach:
	
	To accomplish huffman coding, I used a hash table as my workhorse data structure. I first use the hash table to count the number of each character in the file, which is an O(n) operation on an input file with n characters. I then iterate over the nodes in the hash table, and construct a min heap (believe this is actually O(1) since there are a fixed maximum number of possible characters in the hash table and queue), with each heap node storing character and its count. I pop off the queue, combining nodes until there is a single root node remaining. I then destroy the heap, and use the tree to generate the codes (again I believe this is O(1) since there are a fixed maximum number of possible characters in the tree). I accomplish this by traversing the entire tree, tracking the path I took from the root to every node. When I reach a leaf node, I grab the key from that node and look up the corresponding hash table node. I set the hash table code = the path I took to leaf node. I store the dict (used for encoding) and the tree (used for decoding) in the interface state. When I recieve a new file to encode, I iterate over it char by char. I lookup the input chars in the huffman dict, and print the corresponding huffman code to stdout and an output file. When decoding, I read in bit by bit, and traverse the huffman tree with the directions provided by the bit. Every time I get to a leaf node, I print the leaf's key to std out and output file. To "dump" the dict, I put every node from the hash table into an array and use merge sort to sort it lexigraphically.

Encode

Original Size: 26792 bits
Encoded Size: 14487 bits
Compression Ratio: 0.540721
